She gained widespread recognition for her role as Sera, a troubled prostitute, opposite Nicolas Cage in Leaving Las Vegas (1995). Shue’s performance in this film was highly acclaimed and earned her nominations for the Academy Award, Golden Globe, and BAFTA for Best Actress. Her portrayal was deeply emotional and brought new dimensions to her career, showing her depth as an actress beyond the "girl next door" roles she’d previously played.

I was in middle school when this came out. My dad was super strict and censored all of my music, TV, movies, friends…you name it. My friend asked me to go see Mermaids with her and I asked my dad expecting a hard no. Surprisingly he said yes! So we went with my friends mom and watched it and I LOVED it. Later on I was discussing it with my dad (still didn’t know why he let me go to a pg-13 movie) and it came out he thought I was going to see The Little Mermaid 😳 He was PISSED to say the least 🤣 To this day Mermaids still sticks out as my first pg-13 movie I didn’t have to sneak to see.

Right-wing Americans not only don't know how to recognize fascism, you guys obviously also don't know that a republic is a democracy. 

Those two words are not mutually exclusive. They describe 2 aspects of the same thing. A car can be red and fast at the same time.

"Democracy" describes WHO rules: the people.

"Republic" describes HOW the people rule: by electing representatives.

Every democracy is either a republic (the US, Germany, Ireland, France, etc) or a constitutional monarchy (where even the king must obey the people's laws, like in the UK, Sweden, Denmark, Spain, etc)

I listen to jazz, most of it recorded decades ago by musicians who have been dead for a long time. So I'm not current on recent pop music. One prodigy worth knowing is Julian Lage, the jazz guitarist. He's a once-in-a-generation talent. 

I agree the industry has changed. Q cut his teeth playing jazz trumpet in the early '50s, when a few big bands still existed. He had to be a fluent sight reader, and he had a context for knowing how arrangements "work." He was surrounded by surviving big-band-era jazz musicians who were amazing musicians. That kind of incubator hardly exists today.

I just finished the Joni Mitchell biography yesterday. Amazing talent. It's a pity she blew her soprano range smoking four packs a day. And it's a pity she's been so outspoken. In quote after quote, she says hateful things about just about everyone. Knowing when to shut up would have helped her. As much as I like her music, her sharp tongue is an unattractive feature.
